title: The Keeper of Traken
dialogue_triumphs: This type's not really my forté.
goofs: The Doctor's nose appears different when he's imprisoned in episode three, possibly due to lack of a handkerchief.
Kassia's red eyes are clearly 'painted' on her eyelids (similar to 'Planet of Evil').
The Master's teeth are painted onto his lips.
The Master was clearly seen to be regenerating at the end of 'The Deadly Assassin', so his appearance in a decayed form here is inconsistent.

continuity_notes.name: N-space
continuity_notes.description: A dimension much larger than E-space

continuity_notes.name: Traken Union
continuity_notes.description: The most harmonious union the Universe has ever seen
continuity_notes.current_status: Attracts evil, which is calcified on contact with the planet

continuity_notes.name: The Keeper
continuity_notes.description: The 'organising principle' of all the minds of the Traken Union
continuity_notes.current_status: Capable of penetrating and controlling the TARDIS

continuity_notes.name: The Master
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord renegade and the Doctor's nemesis
continuity_notes.current_status: Claims to have passed through all twelve regenerations

continuity_notes.name: Adric
continuity_notes.current_status: Claims to be 'quite good with locks' but doesn't understand keys

roots: Le Guin's 'The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas'
links: The Doctor's recall to Gallifrey ('Meglos'/'Full Circle') is mentioned again
The Master's TARDIS appears as a grandfather clock ('The Deadly Assassin')

locations.name: Traken
locations.description: Planet in Mettula Orionsis, known for its harmonious union
locations.current_status: Attracts evil, which is calcified on contact with the planet

untold_adventures: The Doctor isn't sure if he's been to Traken before
additional_notes: The Doctor consults two old hand-written time logs, presumably detailing some of his journeys, but says that he doesn't keep them any more.
bottom_line: A beautiful tale, with good and evil taken straight from fairy tales and fables. The poetic dialogue, matched by the design, helps obscure the relative disappointment of the last couple of episodes. But its great revelations and awkward attitude to SF raise 'The Keeper of Traken' above much that surrounds it.
